Sawaddee ka today on hot Thai kitchen it's getting 
boozy it's the time of year for fun and festive

cocktails so I figured I'd show you how you can 
add some Thai flavor flare into your New Year's

Eve cocktail so we're first going to look at how 
you can infuse some Thai herbs into your alcohol

and then in the sequel to this video we're going 
to take our infused alcohol and make a signature

cocktail that I created specifically for hot Thai 
Kitchen so let's get started so infusing alcohol

is really as simple as putting herbs into the 
alcohol and just waiting for it to do its thing

now you can infuse pretty much any kind of herb 
you want but some good choices good tight races

for cocktails are kaffir lime leaves lemongrass 
Thai basil and even Thai chilies but first let's

talk about alcohol vodka is the most common 
choice because it's the most neutral tasting

so you don't have to worry about whether the 
flavor the herb is going to match the flavor

of the alcohol having said that you can infuse 
anything you wish rum gin or whatever because

some things do make a good pair like coconut 
and rum and you certainly don't need expensive

alcohol for this however you do want it to 
be a decent quality because if you start out

with crappy alcohol you're just going to end up 
with crappy infused alcohol you want the flavor

of the alcohol to be clean and smooth so that 
it serves as an onion truce if canvas for your

infusion well there's not much to show here but 
I'll show you anyway I'll give you two examples

I'm doing one with kaffir lime leaves and one 
with Thai chilies now with the lime leaves I'm

using about three full leaves per cup go in 
there and then for the chilies I'm using about

two now I'm leaving these whole if you want them 
spicier or if you want them to infuse faster can

make little incisions in the chilies and that 
will help it a little bit and be careful though

this can get really really spicy so how long do 
you keep this for I like to do mine about five

days to a week before I need it however if you 
need it sooner it's not that big of a deal all

you have to do is add more in so I do a little 
more but then any leftovers I'll take out the

leaves and that way it doesn't keep infusing and 
become too strong the way to test it to know if

it's done is taste it pretty much I just open it 
you'll be able to smell this almost right away

especially the kaffir lime leaves but then it 
won't be very strong yet so just taste it you

can open it and taste it every day if you'd like 
and once it is where you want it to be then you're

done if by accident you let it become too strong 
not a problem you can dilute it with some extra

plain vodka or you can just dilute it when you're 
doing your cocktail so store this in a place out

of direct sunlight and shake it every once in 
a while because what is happening is the flavor

molecules is slowly migrating out of the herbs 
into the vodka so by shaking it you help spread

everything out and speed up the process a little 
bit and now if you click here I'm going to show

you how you can take these to infuse alcohols and 
turn them into a delicious Thai inspired cocktail
